Posts.Content: Feb 14, 2009 11:33PM - edited Feb 14, 2009 11:44PM by See Hi Ladies, I am 44, left side Lumpectomy, <1cm IDC, NodesÂ 0/8 , PRÂ and ER +, Her2Â Neg, Stage 1 , grade 2, no family history of BC. If all went well , I shall be starting 25 rounds of Â rads Monday. Did the markings yesterday. Was rather nervous at first and feels funny having them "drawing" on my body like I am a piece of canvas for them to paint on . Was not too happy with my onc(2nd onc)Â Â . The first one wanted me to do bone and ct scan of which i decline and decide to switch onc asÂ I don't like his face Â . I like my breast surgeon she is so much more considerate of my finance (I don't have insurance). Will beÂ doing aÂ chestÂ x rayÂ (??) on Monday andÂ ultra sound on abdomen (do anyone have US on their abdomen done?I wander if it is necessary to the the US of my abdoment or just another way for onc to earn $$$, the onc clinic is new and hardly have any patients ). My lumpectomy was done by another center. I pick a different center to do my rads as it's nearer my home so that it makes my dailyÂ traveling less stressful. Â Breast surgeon says no need Chemo just Rads . Onc propose chemo which he says put me intoÂ  4% less chance of recurrence which I decline much to his disappointment (could see his disappointed look) All the best to the other rads ladies.

Posts.Content: Feb 4, 2017 06:57PM Did-not-see-this-coming wrote: Yesterday was a big day - got my last drain out and got my first prosthetic! I have to wait about 4 more weeks before I can get my permanent one, but at least I'll feel like I can go back to work in another week and look half way normal. Pain question - almost 3 weeks out, and I'm still having a lot of pain. I swear I have a bruised rib, my muscle is in a ball under my armpit, I have shooting pain in my arm and the skin on my chest is on fire!!!! I do start PT this week - very limited ROM on the surgical arm. Sorry for the rant, but I

Posts.Content: Feb 8, 2017 11:13AM Did-not-see-this-coming wrote: Cowboy-up - are you doing any kind of PT? The reason I ask is that the post-op exercises weren't cutting it, and I was getting progressively stiffer. Have only had one session so far, but the different exercises I got are a game changer. Hope you feel better
Posts.Title: January 2017 Surgery Group BeachBabyK Elem

Posts.Content: Feb 8, 2017 11:25AM Did-not-see-this-coming wrote: Lisabekind - I'm part of the armpit lump club also. My PT thinks it is a swollen lymph node, and I have to say that it decreased in size some after my first lymph massage. My nodes were clean, and her explanation that there are fewer nodes to do the job with lots of inflammation to still reduce made sense to me. I have a follow-up in another two weeks with my surgeon, and I'm hoping it's gone or greatly reduced by then. Good luck!!

Glad to hear many sharing stories outside of cancer - it means we're moving on to a life without cancer!!

I still have one drain in which isn't going to get pulled until next Friday. My doctor also said it's a normal part of the healing process, but that it could take awhile to go away - hang in there!!

Posts.Content: Jan 8, 2017 08:31PM Did-not-see-this-coming wrote: Ok ladies - I'll fess up that I'm a nurse, and that I used to work in endoscopy!! As far as lack of pooping, remember that for every day you don't eat it's at least 2 days of not pooping, and that the pain meds will bind you up something fierce for a few days. I used to like to mix milk of mag and prune juice in with some coffee and serve it warm to patients - the Bronx Bomb worked like a charm!!!! It gives me a bit of a different perspective, because there is nothing that grosses me out other than phlegm - it's my Kriptonite!!! Hoping everyone gets pooping soon - hugs!!
Posts.Title: January 2017 Surgery Group BeachBabyK Elem

I've been up for a walk and did my first set of exercises - while not great, you should be functional!! Good luck today - I agree with everyone before that it is such s relief when it's over
Posts.Title: January 2017 Surgery Group BeachBabyK Elem

Posts.Content: Jan 19, 2017 12:36PM Did-not-see-this-coming wrote: Second day post-op and I feel more like a truck hit me today! I think that the tape holding my drains in place is bothering me more than anything - it's making my skin raw. I got to see my incision today, and it's actually really nice - my underarm is a little more raw, but it's more skin irritation than anything else. The strangest sensation is the numbness - I know that some of it is here to stay. I don't get to take a shower until the drains come out, which is next Wednesday at the earliest. Trying to use my arm as much as possible and not let my shoulders tighten up. Hope everyone else is holding up well!
Posts.Title: January 2017 Surgery Group BeachBabyK Elem

While we share a bond, each of our stories is unique - we'll all be here to listen!! Hugs!

Posts.Content: Jan 29, 2017 03:50PM Did-not-see-this-coming wrote: Elem: arm raising after mastectomy has a lot to with the kind of flap they create during surgery and surgeon preference. I actually had no restrictions post surgery, but still can't raise my arm up much past 90 degrees. I think once I get this last drain out I might do better - I think it's coiled in my armpit!!!! I'm not supposed to go until Friday, but I'm down to under 30cc q24 hours, and I hope I can get it pulled early. He actually may start taking some staples out Friday which would be nice. I still have a lot of numbness and underarm pain, which was the part I wasn't prepared for. I know everyone is different, but I was surprised at how this hung on. Best advice is just listen to your body!
Posts.Title: January 2017 Surgery Group BeachBabyK Elem

Posts.Content: Feb 5, 2017 10:34AM Did-not-see-this-coming wrote: Vargadoll and Fightingirl: even with my limited ROM I found out pretty quickly that I could get pulllover tops on if they were really stretchy or had a zipper neck like most of my fleece tops. Put the surgical arm in first, pull it over your head, then get the other arm in - saved me from dressing in my husband's clothes forever!! Fightingirl: could you actually see/feel your cords? I'm finding the nerve pain worse than anything - the second I get cold it fires off!! Hope everyone has a lovely, shit fairy-free day
Posts.Title: January 2017 Surgery Group BeachBabyK Elem

Posts.Content: Feb 6, 2017 04:18PM Did-not-see-this-coming wrote: My surgeon did say that there was evidence linking a low fat low sugar diet to better outcomes post cancer treatment. He had me get a book called the Pink Ribbon diet - it should be here in the next day or two and I'll share if I think it's worth it!! With that being said, I believe there is balance in maintaining a healthy lifestyle and enjoying the things you love. Fightingirl: had my first PT today, and we decided it's a big lymph node under my arm - I loved the lymph massage!!
Posts.Title: January 2017 Surgery Group BeachBabyK Elem

Posts.Content: Feb 15, 2017 09:40PM Did-not-see-this-coming wrote: Frustrating day - a month post-op and 2 weeks into PT and I still have a golf ball sized bunched up muscle in my armpit and no plan. While he doesn't think I'll need chemo, no one ever thought I would have BC either!! My scars look good, but I'm a bit misshapen on the side - I think it's muscle pulling skin in. Should be working on a project, but just going to bed instead... Thanks for the rant space - sweet dreams all

My final pathology report was posted on my health portal, and I decided to look. 5 additional nodes were reviewed besides the sentinel node, and all clear - 0/5!! Everything else was the same as my biopsy, so no surprises ðŸ˜Š I will have to take the estrogen blocker because I was positive, but I've been menopausal for a few years so I don't imagine I'll notice must change. I'm not having incisionallpain, but my armpit is driving my crazy with the numb/ nerve pain - how's everyone else doing with that? I'm trying to cut off the narcs, but I'm finding I can't make it all day. Ladies from earlier in the month - how long did it take for you to feel pseudo normal after MX?
